etymology.description: Uncertain; Shuowen: ideogrammic/phono-semantic — semantic 匸 (“conceal”) + phonetic 八 (“eight”), a cloth-measure idea (not supported by earliest forms).
etymology.interpretation: Later scholars linked 八 to the notion of ‘eight folds’ and 匸 to ‘concealing’ the ends when rolling cloth, to explain its use as a cloth measure. Early inscriptions don’t clearly show these parts, so the form likely began as an abstract or non-decomposable sign that was later reinterpreted and extended to senses like ‘to match’ and as a classifier.

examples.chinese: 我们需要找到一对颜色相匹配的袜子(我們需要找到一對顏色相匹配的襪子)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen xūyào zhǎodào yī duì yánsè xiāng pǐpèi de wàzi.
examples.english: We need to find a pair of socks that match in color.

examples.chinese: 商店卖一匹布够做两件衣服(商店賣一匹布夠做兩件衣服)。
examples.pinyin: Shāngdiàn mài yì pǐ bù gòu zuò liǎng jiàn yīfu.
examples.english: The store sells a bolt of cloth, enough to make two garments.

examples.chinese: 草原上有两匹马在奔跑(草原上有兩匹馬在奔跑)。
examples.pinyin: Cǎoyuán shàng yǒu liǎng pǐ mǎ zài bēnpǎo.
examples.english: Two horses are galloping on the grassland.
